clinical_study.brief_title: Danazol Treatment in Endometriosis Women Before IVF
clinical_study.official_title: Treatment With Danazol Before Controlled Ovarian Hyperstimulation in Women With Endometriosis Undergoing IVF

lead_sponsor.agency: Centre for Endocrinology and Reproductive Medicine, Italy

clinical_study.source: Centre for Endocrinology and Reproductive Medicine, Italy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether pre-treatment with danazol for at least 4 months before controlled ovarian hyperstimulation for IVF cycles improves pregnancy rate.

detailed_description.textblock: Endometriosis is a chronic benign disease defined by the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity, affecting women in their reproductive age. This disease is clinically characterized by infertility pelvic pain and the presence of ovarian cysts, endometriomas, and affects the about 10% of women. Women with endometriosis when undergo IVF show lower pregnancy rate than general population, and a reduced ovarian reserve, due to the diseases and often to ovarian surgery. The aim of this study is to evaluate if a pre-treatment with danazol, an anti-estrogenic agent, may improve the otcome of IVF cycles in these women

primary_outcome.description: number of ongoing pregnancy for the number of IVF cycles

secondary_outcome.description: number of embryos implanted for the total number of embryos transferred

other_outcome.description: number of mature oocyte collected for patient undergoing IVF

arm_group.description: patients treated with placebo for at least 4 months before IVF attempt
patients treated with danazol (100mg/day)for at least 4 months before IVF attempt

intervention.description: 100 mg day for 4 monthh in women with diagnosed endometriosis before IVF
administered daily like the active comparator

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of endometriosis previous laparoscopic surgery for ovarian endometriotic cysts infertility
Exclusion Criteria:
- age more than 40 years systemic disease antimulleran hormone (AMH)<1 and FSH>20
